row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the Third Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 2.0 percent after increasing 2.6 percent, reflecting an acceleration in imports, a larger decrease in residential investment, and decelerations in consumer spending for services, inventory investment, and state and local government spending. Corporate profits picked up.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade for the Third Quarter of 2006
row.Description: The estimates, including the estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions: Third Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Matthew J. Argersinger, Erin M. Whitaker
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit increased $8.4 billion to $225.6 billion as a result of increases in the deficits on goods and income. In the financial account, net financial inflows increased $23.2 billion to $176.4 billion.

row.Title: An Ownership-Based Framework of the U.S. Current Account, 1995–2005
row.Description: The updated supplement to the international transactions accounts highlights the participation of multinational companies in the international markets for goods and services through both cross-border trade and sales by local affiliates.

row.Title: State Personal Income: Third Quarter of 2006
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income growth for the Nation accelerated, increasing 1.4 percent after increasing 0.4 percent. Growth in all the regions accelerated.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2006 and for 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 3.4 percent after increasing 2.0 percent, reflecting a downturn in imports and accelerations in consumer spending for nondurable goods, in exports, and in Federal, state, and local government spending. In 2006, real GDP increased 3.4 percent after increasing 3.2 percent.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Alternative Measures of Personal Saving
row.Author: Marshall B. Reinsdorf
row.Description: In 2005, NIPA annual personal saving, at –0.4 percent of disposable personal income, was negative for the first time since 1933. Like the NIPA measure, four alternative measures show that personal saving has fallen in the last two decades, but their levels differ from the NIPA measure.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Integrated Macroeconomic Accounts for the United States
row.Author: Charlotte Anne Bond, Teran Martin, Susan Hume McIntosh, Charles Ian Mead
row.Description: BEA and the Federal Reserve Board have developed integrated accounts that relate U.S. economic activity to changes in net worth for the major sectors of the U.S. economy.

row.Title: U.S. National Income and Product Statistics: Born of the Great Depression and World War II
row.Author: Rosemary D. Marcuss, Richard E. Kane
row.Description: The initial national income and product accounts were created in the wake of two crises: The Great Depression and World War II. The story of the early accounts illustrates the scholarly debates that gave way to the compromises required to produce these accounts when they were most needed.
row.Category: National, U.S. national income and product statistics

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 2.2 percent after increasing 2.0 percent, reflecting a downturn in imports and accelerations in consumer spending, in exports, and in Federal, state, and local government spending. Real disposable personal income increased 5.3 percent after increasing 3.2 percent.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Federal Budget Estimates for Fiscal Year 2008
row.Author: Mary L. Roy, Andrew P. Cairns
row.Description: Each year, BEA prepares estimates of Federal Government current receipts and expenditures that are based on the proposed Budget of the U.S. Government. The analysis of these translated estimates can be used to gauge the effects of the Federal budget on U.S. economic activity.
row.Supp1_Title: New Transactions in the NIPA Federal Sector

row.Title: Research and Development Activities of U.S. Multinational Companies: Preliminary Results From the 2004 Benchmark Survey
row.Author: Daniel R. Yorgason
row.Description: In 1999–2004, R&D expenditures of U.S. multinational companies grew at a 4-percent average annual rate after growing at a 7-percent rate in 1994–99. The R&D employment of these companies was 998,000 in 2004, up from 770,000 in 1999.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: The Internal Markets of Multinational Firms
row.Author: Mihir A. Desai, C. Fritz Foley, James R. Hines Jr.
row.Description: The authors summarized their recent studies of the internal markets of multinational corporations. Their research was based on BEA's firm-level international data, available through a program that allows researchers to work at BEA as special sworn employees.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 2.5 percent after increasing 2.0 percent, reflecting a downturn in imports and accelerations in consumer spending, exports, and Federal Government spending. Corporate profits decreased $4.9 billion after increasing $61.5 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)
row.Supp1_Title: Defense Spending for Goods and Services Shipped Abroad

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: Estimates for the Fourth Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Gilda D. Lee
row.Description: Net government saving increased $33.7 billion to –$149.6 billion. Net Federal Government saving increased $41.8 billion to –$131.2 billion. Net state and local government saving decreased $8.2 billion to –$18.4 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)
row.Supp1_Title: Defense Spending for Goods and Services Shipped Abroad

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade for the Fourth Quarter of 2006
row.Description: These estimates, including the estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions: Fourth Quarter of 2006
row.Author: Matthew J. Argersinger, Erin M. Whitaker
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit decreased $33.6 billion to $195.8 billion, mainly reflecting a decrease in the deficit on goods. In the financial account, net financial inflows decreased $65.1 billion to $164.6 billion.

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions in 2006
row.Author: Christopher L. Bach
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit increased $65.1 billion to $856.7 billion, reflecting an increase in the deficit on goods and a shift to a deficit on income. The surplus on services increased. In the financial account, net financial inflows decreased $66.3 billion to $719.1 billion.

row.Title: State Personal Income: Fourth Quarter of 2006 and Annual Estimates for 2006
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income growth for the Nation was 1.2 percent in the fourth quarter of 2006. Growth accelerated in 18 states and decelerated in 25 states. In 2006, personal income growth for the Nation accelerated, increasing 6.3 percent after increasing 5.2 percent.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the First Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 1.3 percent after increasing 2.5 percent, reflecting a downturn in exports, an upturn in imports, a deceleration in consumer spending for nondurable goods, and a downturn in Federal Government spending.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Returns for Domestic Nonfinancial Business
row.Author: Paul R. Lally, George M. Smith, Andrew W. Hodge, Robert J. Corea
row.Description: BEA publishes aggregate rates of returns and Q-ratios roughly once a year. In 2006, the rate of return for nonfinancial corporations increased, continuing a trend that began in 2002. For this first time, rates of returns for various industries and industry groups are also presented.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Annual Industry Accounts: Advance Estimates for 2006
row.Author: Thomas F. Howells III, Kevin B. Barefoot
row.Description: U.S. economic growth reflected accelerated growth in both the private services-producing sector and the private goods-producing sector.
row.Supp1_Title: Comparing Aggregate Measures of Goods and Services Production in BEA's Industry and National Accounts

row.Title: Local Area Personal Income for 2005
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income in most of the Nation's 3,111 counties slowed in 2005. Nonmetropolitan counties grew slower than metropolitan counties. Personal income growth in some counties, especially in Louisiana, was significantly affected by natural disasters.

row.Title: BEA Regional Program Outreach in 2007
row.Description: BEA's regional economic accounts provide detailed estimates of gross state product and personal income for states, counties, and metropolitan areas. To help users better understand and use these accounts, BEA participates in various conferences and workshops around the country.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the First Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 0.6 percent after increasing 2.5 percent, reflecting an upturn in imports, downturns in exports and Federal Government spending, and a deceleration in consumer spending for nondurable goods.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: Estimates for the First Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Pamela A. Kelly
row.Description: Net government saving decreased $32.4 billion to –$171.6 billion. Net Federal Government saving decreased $13.0 billion to –$133.7 billion. Net state and local government saving decreased $19.5 billion to –$37.9 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: U.S. Travel and Tourism Satellite Accounts for 1998–2006
row.Author: Paul V. Kern, Edward A. Kocis
row.Description: The travel and tourism industry grew for the fifth consecutive year in 2006, according to the most recent estimates. The updated estimates reflect several methodological improvements, such as the inclusion of vacation rental homes.
row.Category: Industry, Travel and tourism satellite accounts

row.Title: A Proposal To Include Motor Vehicle Services in the U.S. Travel and Tourism Satellite Accounts
row.Author: Sumiye Okubo, Barbara M. Fraumeni, Mahnaz Fahim-Nader
row.Description: Motor vehicles are widely used in the United States for travel and tourism. However, in keeping with international guidelines, the travel and tourism accounts do not include most motor vehicle services. Accounting for such services would require several changes to the current accounts.
row.Category: Industry, Travel and tourism satellite accounts

row.Title: Foreign Direct Investment in the United States: New Investment in 2006
row.Author: Lawrence R. McNeil
row.Description: Outlays for foreign investors to acquire or establish U.S. businesses increased $70.1 billion to $161.5 billion, coinciding with faster economic growth in the United States and several major investing countries.
row.Category: International, Foreign direct investment in the United States

row.Title: Health Care Studies From the 2007 ASSA Meetings
row.Description: This special section includes four papers on timely health care accounting issues that were discussed in a BEA-organized session at the Allied Social Sciences Association meetings in January. Summaries of other studies that deal with cost measurements by disease are also included.

row.Title: Subject Guide for January–June 2006
row.Description: The guide lists the articles and other information published in these issues of the Survey.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the First Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 0.7 percent after increasing 2.5 percent, reflecting an upturn in imports, a deceleration in exports, a downturn in Federal Government spending, and a deceleration in consumer spending for nondurable goods.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade for the First Quarter of 2007
row.Description: These estimates, including estimates of inventories for manufacturing by stage of fabrication, have been updated.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: The International Investment Position of the United States at Yearend 2006
row.Author: Elena L. Nguyen
row.Description: The net international investment position was –$2,539.6 billion; in 2005, it was –$2,238.4 billion. The change was mainly due to especially strong net foreign purchases of U.S. securities.

row.Title: Direct Investment Positions for 2006: Country and Industry Detail
row.Author: Marilyn Ibarra, Jennifer Koncz
row.Description: The historical-cost position of both U.S. direct investment abroad and foreign direct investment abroad increased 12 percent. In 2005, U.S. direct investment abroad increased 1 percent, while foreign direct investment abroad increased 5 percent.
row.Category: International, Direct investment positions: Country and industry detail

row.Title: Annual Revision of the U.S. International Accounts for 1997–2006
row.Author: Christopher L. Bach
row.Description: Each year, these estimates of U.S. transactions and of the U.S. international investment position are revised to incorporate statistical and methodological changes. This year, the revision incorporated new estimates of transactions in financial derivatives.

row.Title: How BEA Aligns and Augments Source Data From the U.S. Treasury Department for Inclusion in the International Transactions Accounts
row.Description: Each year, these estimates of financial-account flows in the international transactions accounts, which are based on Treasury Department data, are adjusted to align the estimates with balance-of-payments concepts and to close gaps in coverage.

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions: First Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Renee M. Sauers
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit increased $4.6 billion, reflecting an increase in net unilateral current transfers to foreigners and a small increase in the deficit on goods. In the financial account, net financial inflows decreased $24.2 billion to $202.8 billion.

row.Title: Gross Domestic Product by State: Advance Estimates for 2006 and Revised Estimates for 2003–2005
row.Author: Clifford H. Woodruff III, Sharon D. Panek, Timothy P. McInerney
row.Description: Economic growth in the United States was widespread in 2006; inflation-adjusted gross domestic product grew in 49 states and the District of Columbia.
row.Category: Regional, Gross domestic product by state

row.Title: State Personal Income: First Quarter of 2007
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income for the Nation grew 2.2 percent after growing 1.4 percent. Personal income growth was higher than the national average in just five states. Growth in these states reflected strong finance industry activity.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2007
row.Description: Real GDP increased 3.4 percent after increasing 0.6 percent in the first quarter, reflecting an upturn in imports, a deceleration in exports, a downturn in Federal Government spending, and a deceleration in consumer spending for nondurable goods.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Annual Revision of the National Income and Product Accounts: Annual Estimates for 2004–2006 and Quarterly Estimates for the First Quarter of 2004–the First Quarter of 2007
row.Description: For 2004–2006, real GDP growth at an average annual rate was revised to 3.2 percent from 3.5 percent. For the fourth quarter of 2003 through the first quarter of 2007, real GDP growth was revised to 2.7 percent from 3.0 percent.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)
row.Supp1_Title: Recent Revisions to Real GDP Growth Rates

row.Title: National Income and Product Accounts Tables
row.Description: The revised annual, quarterly, and monthly estimates from the annual NIPA revision are presented in these tables. Advance estimates for the second quarter of 2007 and for June 2007 are included in the PDFs below.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: GDP and Other Major NIPA Series for 1929–the Second Quarter of 2006
row.Description: Historical estimates of GDP and its components in current dollars, chained dollars, and chain-type quantity and price indexes are presented as part of the annual NIPA revision. This series includes estimates of national income and personal income.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: U.S. Affiliates of Foreign Companies: Operations in 2005
row.Description: Growth in the current-dollar value added of majority-owned nonbank U.S. affiliates slowed in 2005. Employment by affiliates fell for the fifth consecutive year.
row.Category: International, Operations of U.S. affiliates of foreign companies

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 4.0 percent after increasing 0.6 percent. The acceleration reflected a downturn in imports, upturns in Federal Government spending and inventory investment, accelerations in exports and nonresidential structures, and a smaller decrease in residential investment.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Pamela A. Kelly
row.Description: Net government saving increased $40.9 billion to –$183.4 billion. Net Federal Government saving increased $27.1 billion to –$191.4 billion. Net state and local government saving increased $13.8 billion to $8.0 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Newly Available NIPA Tables
row.Description: As part of the annual NIPA revision, estimates of government spending by function, changes in the net stock of produced assets, and the relationship between NIPA and USDA net farm income measures are presented.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Fixed Assets and Consumer Durable Goods for 1997–2006
row.Author: David B. Wasshausen
row.Description: Statistics on the net stock of equipment and software, structures owned by business and government, and the new stock of durable goods owned by consumers reflect the annual NIPA revision.
row.Category: National, Fixed assets and consumer durable goods

row.Title: Foreign Direct Investment in the United States: Detail for Historical-Cost Position and Related Capital and Income Flows for 2004–2006
row.Author: Jeffrey H. Lowe
row.Description: Estimates of the direct investment position and international transactions of foreign multinational companies and the composition of investment by foreign companies in the United States are presented.
row.Category: International, Foreign direct investment in the United States

row.Title: U.S. Direct Investment Abroad: Detail for Historical-Cost Position and Related Capital and Income Flows for 2004–2006
row.Author: Jeffrey H. Lowe
row.Description: Estimates of the direct investment position and international transactions of U.S. multinational companies and the composition of investment by U.S. companies abroad are presented.

row.Title: Personal Income for Metropolitan Areas for 2006
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Personal income growth accelerated in nearly 70 percent of the Nation's 363 metropolitan areas in 2006. Growth in metropolitan areas averaged 6.3 percent, up from 5.3 percent in 2005.
row.Category: Regional, Personal income for metropolitan areas

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Final Estimates for the Second Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 3.8 percent in the second quarter after increasing 0.6 percent in the first quarter. The acceleration reflected a downturn in imports and upturns in Federal Government spending and inventory investment.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Newly Available NIPA Tables
row.Description: The relationship between NIPA Federal receipts and expenditures and the Federal budget, the relationship between NIPA state and local government spending and Census Bureau data, a comparison of NIPA personal income and IRS adjusted gross income, and more.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Real Inventories, Sales, and Inventory-Sales Ratios for Manufacturing and Trade
row.Description: These estimates for the fourth quarter of 2003 through the second quarter of 2007 reflect the most recent annual revision of the national income and product accounts.
row.Category: National, Inventories, sales, and inventory-sales ratios for manufacturing and trade

row.Title: U.S. Benchmark Input-Output Accounts, 2002
row.Author: Ricky L. Stewart, Jessica Brede Stone, Mary L. Streitwieser
row.Description: The benchmark input-output (I-O) account for 2002 provides a highly detailed view of the inner workings of the economy. Benchmark I-O accounts are published every five years.
row.Supp1_Title: Uses of the Benchmark I-O Accounts

row.Title: Research and Development Satellite Account Update
row.Author: Carol A. Robbins, Carol E. Moylan
row.Description: The 2007 version of the R&D account updates and extends previous estimates. For the first time, it provides estimates about the impact of R&D investment on industries, regional economies, and international economic transactions and positions.
row.Category: National, Research and development satellite account
row.Supp2_Title: How R&D Investment Affects GDP and GDI

row.Title: U.S. International Services: Cross-Border Trade in 2006 and Sales Through Affiliates in 2005
row.Author: Jennifer Koncz, Anne Flatness
row.Description: The surplus on cross-border trade in private services was $96.6 billion in 2006, up from $86.2 billion in 2005. Sales abroad via foreign affiliates were $139.5 billion more than U.S. purchases from U.S. affiliates of foreign companies in 2005; the difference in 2004 was $101.1 billion.
row.Supp2_Title: Supplemental Estimates of Insurance, Trade Services, and Financial Services Sold Through Affiliates

row.Title: U.S. International Transactions for the Second Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Erin M. Whitaker, Jessica Melton Hanson
row.Description: The U.S. current-account deficit decreased to $190.8 billion in the second quarter of 2007 from $197.1 billion in the first quarter, reflecting a decrease in net unilateral current transfers to foreigners and increases in the surpluses on services and income.

row.Title: State Personal Income for the Second Quarter of 2007 and Revised Estimates for 2004–2006
row.Author: David G. Lenze
row.Description: Current-dollar personal income growth slowed in the second quarter of 2007, rising 1.2 percent after rising 2.5 percent in the first quarter. The slowdown partly reflected strong first-quarter personal income growth, which was boosted by large bonuses paid for 2006.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Advance Estimates for the Third Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 3.9 percent after increasing 3.8 percent in the second quarter. The third-quarter growth reflected a rebound in consumer spending and a surge in goods exports. Residential investment continued to decline.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Newly Available NIPA Tables
row.Description: Two tables: Personal income and outlays by households and nonprofit institutions serving households and a comparison of the income and outlays of these nonprofits with IRS revenue and expenses.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Updated Summary of NIPA Methodologies
row.Description: The source data and methods used to prepare current-dollar and real estimates of GDP and current-dollar estimates of gross domestic income have been updated as part of the 2007 annual NIPA revision.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Comparing the Consumer Price Index and the Personal Consumption Expenditures Price Index
row.Author: Clinton P. McCully, Brian C. Moyer, Kenneth J. Stewart
row.Description: This comparison of the CPI from the Bureau of Labor Statistics and the PCE Price Index from the Bureau of Economic Analysis finds that different formulas account for much of the difference in recent growth rates.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Federal Personal Income Tax Liabilities and Payments for 1959–2005
row.Author: Mark A. Ledbetter
row.Description: These updated estimates incorporate the results of the 2007 annual NIPA revision, newly available IRS tax return data for 2003, and revised data for earned income tax credits.
row.Category: National, Federal personal income tax liabilities and payments

row.Title: Comparison of BEA Estimates of Personal Income and IRS Estimates of Adjusted Gross Income: New Estimates for 2005 and Revised Estimates for 2004
row.Author: Mark Ledbetter
row.Description: The estimates of these two widely used measures of household income are reconciled in order to account for statistical and definitional differences.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Operations of U.S. Multinational Companies in 2005
row.Author: Sharon D. Panek, Frank T. Baumgardner, Matthew J. McCormick
row.Description: The value added of U.S. multinational companies increased 6.5 percent after averaging 3.8 percent annual growth in 1999–2005. The value added of U.S. parents increased 6 percent. The value added of their foreign affiliates increased 7.8 percent.
row.Supp1_Title: More Countries Collect Data on Multinational Companies

row.Title: Reconciliation of the United States–Canadian Current Account, 2005 and 2006
row.Author: Renee Sauers, Edward Dozier, Denis Caron
row.Description: Each year, the bilateral current-account estimates of the United States and Canada are reconciled to show how the estimates would appear if both countries used the same definitions, methodologies, and data sources.

row.Title: Introducing New Measures of the Metropolitan Economy: Prototype GDP-by-Metropolitan-Area Estimates for 2001–2005
row.Author: Sharon D. Panek, Frank T. Baumgardner, Matthew J. McCormick
row.Description: New prototype estimates of GDP by metropolitan area show that metropolitan areas accounted for 90 percent of the Nation's GDP in 2005. The methodology uses earnings data to estimate output.
row.Category: Regional, Introducing new measures of the metropolitan economy

row.Title: BEA Regional Program Outreach in 2008
row.Description: BEA's regional economic accounts provide detailed economic estimates for states, counties, and metropolitan areas. To help users better understand and use these statistics, BEA participates in various conferences and workshops.

row.Title: Director's Message
row.Author: J. Steven Landefeld
row.Description: Monthly message from BEA Director Steve Landefeld

row.Title: Taking Account
GDP and the Economy: Preliminary Estimates for the Third Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Christopher Swann
row.Description: Real GDP increased 4.9 percent after increasing 3.8 percent in the second quarter. The acceleration reflected accelerations in exports, consumer spending, and inventory investment. Investment in nonresidential structures slowed, and residential investment continued to decline.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Government Receipts and Expenditures: Third Quarter of 2007
row.Author: Debasis Chaudhuri
row.Description: Net government saving decreased $43.4 billion to –$236.8 billion. Net Federal Government saving decreased $22.4 billion to –$229.2 billion. Net state and local government saving decreased $21.1 billion to –$7.7 billion.
row.Category: National, National income and product accounts (NIPAs)

row.Title: Integrating the 2002 Benchmark Input-Output Accounts and the 2002 Annual Industry Accounts
row.Author: Dylan G. Rassier, Thomas F. Howells III, Edward T. Morgan, Nicholas R. Empey, Conrad E. Roesch
row.Description: Better integration of these two accounts has long been a goal of BEA. For the 2002 accounts, a new model was implemented. This BEA Briefing is the first in a series of articles that will explain important aspects of BEA's accounts in less technical language.

row.Title: Subject Guide for 2007
row.Description: This guide lists the articles that were published in the Survey in 2007.

row.Title: Schedule of BEA News Releases in 2008
